title: MODULE 7
subtitle: Navigating the Working World: Finding and Maintaining Employment
description: You probably already know that getting and keeping a job is important for your recovery. It is also likely a requirement of your supervision sentence. You may be currently looking for a job or already have one. Depending on where you are in the job hunt or how satisfied you are with your work, the focus of this module may be more about helping you keep what you have or even move up the chain. If you don’t have a job yet or aren’t satisfied with your work, this module may give you some tools to make needed changes.

pages.text: It’s no secret that landing a job with a criminal record is hard, yet unemployment is a major risk factor for continued criminal behavior. As unfair as it may be, employers feel nervous about hiring people who have been in trouble with the law. This means you will have to dig a little deeper to find a job, be more patient and persistent (don’t get sidetracked by rejection), and work harder to make a good first impression. You may even need to compromise on what types of jobs you’re willing to do. In other words, some job opportunities may seem “below” you, but you need to start somewhere. That doesn’t mean you needto stay in this job forever, but you may need to start lower and work your way back up. Plus, you are required to be employed as part of your supervision rules. Don’t pass up a job simply because it’s not your dream job. In this worksheet, we will focus on getting your mind ready to start looking for a job so you can improve your success of finding and keeping one.
pages.subheader: Getting Your Mind Right for the Job Market

pages.text: Understandably, employers may be worried about hiring someone like you who has broken the law. It is difficult for employers to get away from the “offender” label and see you as the individual you are—outside of past mistakes. To help prevent you from getting discouraged by questions employers may ask about your history or feeling frustrated with employers who don’t understand you, let’s think about things from their perspective for a minute.

fields.text: If you were hiring for a job and you didn’t have any experience with people who’ve been in the criminal justice system, what fears or concerns would you have about hiring someone with a criminal background?

As you look at your response above, think about what you as the job candidate can do or say to help employers look past these fears. We will talk more about how to use your criminal history to your advantage later in the module.

pages.text: Just as employers might have fears or concerns about hiring you, you may also have worries about the job hunt, the job interview, your qualifications for the job, what others will think if you have to take a less glamorous job, or your ability to keep a job. You may be looking for employment for the first time after being released from jail or prison, you may be starting out on a new career path, or you may be working toward promotion in a current position. Everyone is at different stages and have a different set of stressors.

fields.text: Considering your criminal history and past behavior, what worries are on your mind as you think about finding and/or keeping a good job?

pages.subheader: Understanding Your Own Fears about Employment

pages.text:
By now, you know that your thoughts and feelings have a big impact on your behaviors. This is no different at work. Researchers have found that certain attitudes and ways of thinking about work make people more or less likely to be happy in their jobs and stay in their jobs. People who see their jobs as part of who they are as a person (work is an aspect of their identity), are more successful in their jobs and report greater enjoyment at work. These people think things like:
  • Work should be considered central to life
  • I would probably keep working even if I didn't need the money
  • Overall, I consider work to be very central to my existence
On the other hand, people who seek work only as a means to an end (for example, to make money) or are cynical about work are less successful and happy in their jobs. These people think things like:
  • No matter how hard you work, you never really seem to reach your goals
  • Ordinary work is too boring to be worth doing
  • I don't enjoy work; I just put in my time to get paid
People are also more likely to get a good job they like (or can at least tolerate) if they're confident in themselves, feel in control during the hiring process, and can make compromises when necessary. These people think things like:
  • I feel in control over my job choices
  • I've learned how to find my own way through the world of work
  • In order to provide for my family, I may have to take a job I don't enjoy as much
There have even been a handful of studies on work attitudes among people on community supervision. One study found that those who ended up violating terms of their supervision had more negative views toward work in general and showed more entitlement toward employment opportunities, such as refusing to take lower-end jobs and work toward promotions, than those who successfully completed their supervision sentence.

fields.text: Navigate to the Assessment Center and review your PICTS scores - was entitlement high for you? If so, how might this impact your job search?
Another study found that parolees who saw work as part of their identity and learned how to deal with the stigma associated with their ex-offender status improved their chances of being hired.
What are your attitudes about work?
Which of the statements listed above <u>in bold</u> best match your own attitudes?

Lastly, recall that a positive environment is also important to achieving your goals. If you surround yourself with people who support your job-seeking efforts, you have a better chance of being successful. That means, get away from the people who want you to slack off or earn money by doing things that are illegal. Don’t let other people’s bad attitudes about work impact your own. You will learn in the next module about how to move away from antisocial associates, but we will review how to avoid antisocial associates at work later in the module.

pages.text: Read the following thoughts and first determine if the thought has ever crossed your mind. Then, provide a more positive spin on the thought to increase helpful attitudes about work.

fields.text:
Unhelpful Thought: The only thing that matters in choosing a job is to make ends meet.
Have you ever thought something like this?
Now, think of a more helpful thought:

Unhelpful Thought: Those who work for a living are manipulated by those who run things.
Have you ever thought something like this?
Now, think of a more helpful thought:

Unhelpful Thought: Most of work life is wasted in meaningless activity.
Have you ever thought something like this?
Now, think of a more helpful thought:

Unhelpful Thought: It doesn't matter if people work hard at their jobs; only a few "higher ups" will really profit.
Have you ever thought something like this?
Now, think of a more helpful thought:

Unhelpful Thought: I feel little need to try my best at work because it makes no difference anyway.
Have you ever thought something like this?
Now, think of a more helpful thought:

Unhelpful Thought: Work should only be a small part of one's life.
Have you ever thought something like this?
Now, think of a more helpful thought:

pages.text: Now that your mind is prepped for the job market and you can see the benefits of having a positive attitude about work, let’s take a look at your unique interests and strengths as you get ready to look for jobs that are in line with your interests and strengths. This will help youprepare forinterview questions about why you want the job and what skills you bring to the table.
pages.subheader: Knowing Your Career Interests and Strengths

pages.text:
First, we need to trace your employment steps.You likely have lots of jobs, some official and some more casual, that you have done in the past.Most jobs or volunteer work needsto be included in retracing your work history, but illegaljobs should be left out. You likely learned a lot about hard work and life lessons from illegitimatejobs, but because of their illegal nature, there are obvious reasons why theyshouldn’t be included on an application for a job. Let’s review which jobs should be included in your employment history:
Include things like:
  • Paid jobs in which you were officially hired by a company or person (examples: line cook at a restaurant, delivery person for post office, supervisor at a grocery store)
  • Paid jobs in which you were unofficially hired and possibly paid under the table (examples: street sign holder for phone company, late night busser at family-owned diner)
  • Paid jobs that you held while in jail or prison (you could leave out that the job was specifically in prison; you can say you were a government worker instead; examples: kitchen cook, library organizer, maintenance crew).
  • Paid jobs that you were more casually hired by a person after the age of 14 (examples: babysitting, lawn mowing, gutter cleaning, dog walking, driving factors)
  • Volunteer jobs with an organization or crew (examples: donation organizer at food bank, clean-up crew member after a natural disaster).

Do NOT include things like:
  • Jobs in which you were paid to do illegal things (examples: running drugs for a dealer, manufacturing weapon parts outside of a factory).

What (if any) jobs have you had before? How long were you in those jobs? What did you like about these jobs? What didn’t you like? Were you ever fired from a job? What made it difficult to keep a job? Understanding your job history will help you more clearly see your likes and dislikes, strengths, and barriers.

questions.prompt: Answer the following questions as honestly and accurately as you can:

fields.text: Since the age of 14, approximately how many different jobs have you had?
What was the longest amount of time you ever worked at one place?
What kind of work did you do there?
Have you ever been fired from a job?
if yes, how many times have you been fired? If no, please type "N/A"
If yes, why were you fired? If no, please type "N/A"
Which job (or part of a job) did you like the MOST and why?
Which job (or part of a job) did you like the LEAST and why?

As you look back on your work history—what do you notice? Was it stable? Or did you change jobs a lot? Did you have trouble keeping a job? What feelings come up when you think about your past jobs? Perhaps you’ve been reminded of some things you liked or enjoyed about working. Or perhaps you’re taking note of things you’d like to avoid (like a cranky boss, having to travel far, or dealing with nasty customers).

pages.text:
People have better work experiences when they can link their careers to personal interests. However, you must also think about what is realisticfor you. Maybe one of your interests is basketball. Can you get a job as a player in the NBA? Uh...probably not. Even if you’re very good at basketball and you have a strong passion for it, only a very small number of people get in the NBA. If you aren’t a pro baller by now, best to move on from that dream! Interests are useful, but they must be considered along with your skills and education, or your ability to obtain the necessary skills and education. For example, if you like helping people and want to be a therapist, can you get into and pay for graduate school? On top of that, all this needs to be considered with your criminal history. In other words, findinga job involves knowing about yourself AND what your options realistically are.
One way to look at interests related to jobs is to use a model developed by a psychologist named John Holland. Dr. Hollard came up with 6 interest types that make up the RIASEC model. RIASEC stands for the following: (1) Realistic, (2) Investigative, (3) Artistic, (4) Social, (5) Enterprising, and (6) Conventional. It is often shown in a hexagon shape like what you see below, where types that are close to each other (like artistic and social) more commonly go together than types that are further apart (like artistic and conventional). Read each piece of the hexagon and see which ones feel like you.

To know what your highest interest areas are, there are special tests available! Visit this website for a FREE assessment of your Holland types. This measure will show you your “Holland Code,” which is your 3 highest interest areas.
Copy and paste this link into your internet browser to take the test: https://openpsychometrics.org/tests/RIASEC/

fields.text: After you complete the test, type the 3 letters of your Holland Code here (e.g., I, S, C):

Was your result a surprise? List some ways in which these traits have shown up in your life. For example, if A (artistic) was one of your letters, do you like to doodle, tag graffiti, tattoo? List your own examples for each of your 3 code types in the corresponding text box.
Type 1:
Type 2:
Type 3:

As you look for jobs, keep your code in mind. Do the job tasks or duties tap into these interest areas? This website (https://www.career-lifeskills.com/pdf/jst-576530-occupations.pdf), or a quick Google search for “RIASEC occupations” will also give you a good list of jobs that typically match each interest area. Do any of them speak to you? If so, which ones are realistic given your skills, education, and criminal history?

pages.text: So, you have a better idea about your interests, next let’s focus on your strengths and skills. What do you have to offer? What are you good at? What are your marketable skills? The following are several categories employers and managers look for in job applicants. Rate yourself on each of these domains. Before, you may have shown these skills in antisocial or criminal ways. Think about how they can instead be used to achieve prosocial goals.

questions.prompt: After reading the following domains, rate yourself as "Good" "OK" or "Needs Work"

fields.text: Communication Skills: Reading, writing, speaking, editing, listening, and presenting information clearly.
Creativity: The ability to come up with new and innovative ideas; or solutions to problems.
Critical Thinking: Quickly identifying problems, thinking about the complexity of problems, and looking at options to solve the problem.
Leadership: The ability to set goals and give good direction to a group; taking action on an issue or problem.
Life Management: Good time-management for long-term projects and day-to-day activities; ability to manage details of your life and work.
Project Development: The ability to take an idea and follow-through to a finished product; including planning and coordinating with others.
Social Responsibility: Respecting other peoples' differences and culture; seeing good qualities in others and treating people how you'd like to be treated.
Teamwork: Working well with others in a group; having a commitment to complete a team-based project; sharing responsibilities and doing your part.
Technical Skills: The ability to use current technologies in your job such as computer software (Microsoft Office) or typing skills.
Can you think of other skills you have that might be useful for the job or types of jobs you want?

pages.subheader: Sorting Out Your Strengths and Skills

pages.text: As mentioned, you many have relied on the skills above before but it’s possible you did not use them in productive ways. Many people in the criminal justice system are smart, talented, and have excellent people skills. But, they’ve used these strengths and skills to keep up their criminal lifestyle. Help the people in the following stories re-direct their strengths and skills.

questions.prompt: Lamar had been in prison for the past 7 years for drug possession with intent to sell and is about to be released on parole. Lamar is a smooth-talker and quick with his words. When he first went inside, Lamar used his street sense and communication skills to convince a small circle of inmates and a few correctional officers to help him smuggle in drugs from an outside connection. He quickly rose up the ranks, built a crew of smugglers, and a large customer base. He made good money and kept an organized system. Everyone involved had a lot of trust and respect in Lamar; no one ever ratted on him and prison administrators never found out it was Lamar who was running the show.

fields.text: What STRENGTHS or SKILLS does Lamar have based on this story?
What types of JOBS might he be good at? Think about the RIASEC areas.

Domenica always had the best fashion sense. She had the newest styles of the season and knew how to put pieces together in a way that no one else could do. She had over 2,000 followers on Instagram for her style and fashion advice. Some people who knew her wondered how she was able to keep up with her wardrobe. She didn’t come from a wealthy family and she didn’t seem to work much. Soon enough the police caught up with her actions—Domenica was shoplifting from stores, including some high-end boutiques, posting pictures of herself in various outfits, then selling the items through an online discount store. She would also purchase items online and tell the retailer that she never received the items, allowing her to be refunded for the purchases. Now she’s on probation and facing hefty fines.
What STRENGTHS or SKILLS does Domenica have based on this story?
What types of JOBS might she be good at? Think about the RIASEC areas.

Josef was at the bar all night drinking. He was completely wasted but decided to chug a glass of water and drive home anyway. On his way, he hit a parked car a few blocks from his apartment and ended up crashing into the guardrail. He was ok, only had a few scratch marks. Instead of panicking and reporting the incident to police, Josef remained calm, slowly got out of the car, and walked the rest of the way home. The next morning, he called police to report his car as missing. The police called him back a few hours later saying the car was located but was wrecked. Josef kept his cool and asked police where the car was found. Josef thought he got away with a hit and run, but what he didn’t know what that there was a witness...the owner of the parked car.
What STRENGTHS or SKILLS does Josef have based on this story?
What types of JOBS might he be good at? Think about the RIASEC areas.

pages.text: It can seem easy talking to employers about your experiences and strengths, especially if one of your RIASEC types is Social. But employers often require other materials, like job applications, resumes, and job references before they can hire you. It can be tricky to put togethergood application materials, but it’s importantbecause employers look at your materialswhen you are not around –so if your application or resume doesn’t make sense, or doesn’t give a good impression, it could lessen your chances of getting a call for an interview. You don’t have any opportunity to explain yourself. Your materials need to speak for you. As you start the job hunt (if you haven’t already), use this guide to prepare your application materialsand increase your chances at receiving job interviews.
pages.subheader: Practical Tools for the Job Hunt

pages.text:
Your resume leaves the very first impression on your employer. So, you want to put your best foot forward. There are some things every resume should include, and there are some things that are not required, but may help make your resume stand out.
Bare Essentials
To make a resume that has exactly what your future employer needs to understand your fit for the job, include the following categories:
  • Who you are- include your name and contact information at the top of your resume
  • Education - list in order from most recent education to oldest education. Include the school name, city and state, degree earned, and graduation date (or "present," if you are still enrolled!)
  • Experience - list your previous jobs (identified earlier in the module) with the name of the job, the date you were employed, and a few tasks that you were in charge of for that job.

Jessica’s resume needs to be organized before she applies to the office assistant position at the law firm. Based on the guidelines for organizing resumes and what you know about employment experience, choose whether the following lines of her resume fit into the education or work category.

fields.text: Grocery clerk, Cincinnati, Ohio 9/2008-12/2009
Fountain Springs Elementary School, Springfield, Illinois 8/1990-5/1998
Welding Certification, Cincinnati Technical Training Facility, Cincinnati, Ohio 8/2009-8/2011
Dog walker, Springfield, Illinois 6/1996-9/1996
Construction worker, Habitats for Humanity, Cincinnati, Ohio 3/2010-Present
GED, College Academy, Denton, Ohio 7/2001-6/2002
Line cook, Wyoming State Prison, Bushnell, Wyoming 2/2000-3/2005

pages.text:
After you put all of the necessary information into your resume, check these tips to make sure your resume looks its best:
  • Make sure your resume is no more than 3 pages and only use more than one page if absolutely necessary.
  • Use a simple format with subheadings (Microsoft Word provides several templates to easily create a resume).
  • Use positive descriptive words and action words (to practice using these, see the "What's in a Word?" activity).
  • Keep it short and only include necessary information — this isn't a good place to outline every good thing you have ever done. Only include the things that your employer would want to know about!
  • Be honest on your resume — employers may not know if you lied on your resume or job application, but it definitely won't help if they find out.
  • Be neat — print your resumes on clean paper, and don't fold or bend the copy that you are going to give your employer.

Resumes look extra sharp when the applicant uses positive descriptive and action words to draw attention to their work experience. For example, Jessica’s resume has the following line in her job experience section:
“Build homes for homeless people in Cincinnati.”
The word “build” is an action word that employers like to see. Other words that are positive action words are to act, advise, measure, produce, and evaluate. Review the following lines in Jessica’s resume and rewrite each statement to use positive action words. Feel free to use some of the words in the word bank below.

fields.text: "Helped my boss unpack shipments."
"I asked my neighbors if I could walk their dogs for money."
"Put together food for inmates three times a day."
"Went to parts of the city and fixed houses for families."

pages.text: Thinking about your criminal history and how it may affect your job searchcan be nerve-racking. You might even feel scared or upset about it, especially as you approach the interview. These feelings are normal. When our past decisions come full circle and change our futures, it can be hard to be positive. But you can’t let these feelings discourage you from hunting! You still need a job, and there’s someone out there willing to hire you. You just have to know how to use your criminal history and your experience to your benefit.

Do your homework and prepare. Do a Google search about the employer. Carefully read the job description. Employerswant and are impressed by people who show an interestin them. Knowing some things in advance will help you seem knowledgeable about the job and employer, and help you prepare to answer questions about how you would be a good fit for the job.Here is a list of information you should try to getahead of time. Write these downor take a pictureso you can go back to them later.You may also want to keep a list of questions to ask during the interview. This will show your curiosity to learn more.
  • Name, address, phone number of the company
  • Services offered — what does the company DO?
  • Mission statement of the company — what are their overall goals?
  • Company organization — who runs things? How are employees managed?
  • The job duties of the position you applied for
  • The job skills required to complete the job duties
  • The salary range for the job and benefits
  • Opportunities for promotion and advancement
  • Any major competitors of the company

Did you know that people usually form opinions about other people within about 5-7 seconds of meeting them?! And, once people have a bad impression of you, it’s hard to change their mind. Researchers have done studies on first impressions and have shown this to be true. Often, first impressions are based on your appearance and body language. While that isn’t fair, it is fact. What do you need to do to make a good first impression with employers? Here’s another checklist of what helps.
  • Be on time for your interview—leave extra early in case the bus is late, you get lost, there's unexpected traffic, or you can't find parking. Employers don't like excuses.
  • Wear appropriate clothes —don't wear anything that has holes in it, is too low-cut or too short, is too colorful, or smells gross. If you don't have anything in your closet, borrow something! Try the local Goodwill or Dress for Success. Make sure it fits you before you buy it.
  • Have a bright smile—no one likes when they're told to smile, but smiling makes people feel comfortable and happy to be around you. This is important especially if the job involves customer service. But don't go overboard; people who take this too far can seem fake.
  • Keep an open and confident presence—don't cross your arms, sit up straight, walk tall, keep good eye-contact (not too much or too little), and use a firm hand shake when first introducing yourself; you want to look inviting and like you deserve to be there.
  • Use small talk—you learned about this in the last module. Comment on the weather or the "big game" last week. Find out if you have anything in common with the employer. Don't talk about religion or politics.
  • Be attentive—limit distractions like your phone...don't check your phone or text during an interview! Don't bring food, shopping bags, or your kids. And spit out that gum.
  • Be the best version of yourself—you don't have to completely change who you are; you're just putting your best foot forward to earn trust, respect, and confidence

Even if something in the interview pisses you off—like someone making a rude comment about your criminal history—stick with a positive attitude anyway. You can always say "no" to them later, but you don't want them being the ones slamming the door on you. Be the better person.

Before heading into the interview, you also need to arm yourself with some gearor tricks to help youmake it through. Your criminal history and your experiencecan actually be useful. Use it to your benefit, like thearmorin a suit, along with a few other tipsdiscussed in this worksheet. Your interview armor includes guidelines and suggestions for how to talk about your criminal history in a positive way without disclosing too much and other interview tricks that will show employers that you are serious.

Feeling skeptical about the interview? Worried you’ll get a “no” right off the bat? A skill that will help you use your interview armor includes finding the positive in a negative situation. Use skills you already learned like cognitive restructuring. Can you think of a “flip-side” to these negative situations? It’s easy to focus on what you’re losing or what’s going wrong.The challenge is to find some way you can benefit from the situation or use a second chance to make it better. An example is provided for you.
pages.header: A Quick Review of Cognitive Restructuring

questions.prompt:
Example Situation: My supervising officer told me I couldn't hang out with my friends anymore because they're on community supervision too. We've been through some shit and I've known them since grade school.
Example Flip-Side: Maybe I'll stop getting so drunk on the weekends, like we all used to. I might even spend some time with my sister and her family.

fields.text:
Situation: I haven't seen my kids since I got out of prison. It's been four years since I last saw them, what if they don't remember me?
The Flip-Side:

Situation: I lost my bus pass, and it was the only way I could get to the community supervision department. Now I have to find a ride or walk there to — hopefully — get a replacement.
The Flip-Side:

Situation: I've been applying for liquor store jobs all week — everything from clerk to a stocker. No one's called me back for an interview, and I'm getting impatient.
The Flip-Side:

pages.text:
When you are asked about your criminal history in an interview, you have to answer honestly. Remember, an employer can decide not to hire you, or to fire you later, if you lie on this question. But you can choose what to tell them. This is your first piece of armor, your helmet.
  • Helmet—using your head: Protect the things that are most important to you: your dignity, your privacy, and your right to being respected. When an employer asks you about your criminal history, only tell them what they need to know: whether you were arrested or convicted, what for (a general description, such as theft or substance use), and any important details about what happened that might make you look better to your future employer ("it was only once when I was young" or "I was there when someone else got in trouble, so I was guilty by association"). But only IF THESE THINGS ARE TRUE. Use what makes the most sense for your situation. Don't spend much time on this question — one to two sentences, at most. You also don't want to air your dirty laundry about the judge who screwed you over or the drug dealer who snitched on you. Short and simple is the key here! Stay smart.
  • Sword—your best weapon: A sword is the sharpest weapon you could have — in your case, your sharpest weapon is what you learned from your experience in the system. Think about what you learned about life, mortality, being an adult, or responsibility while in prison or while on community supervision. Tie some of these life lessons into the interview questions. If you offense was stealing, talk about the lessons you learned in integrity, honesty, and how criminal acts affect the entire community. If your offense was something violent, say what you learned about yourself, how you've grown as a person, gotten the help you needed, and the value of respecting others. Then say a few words on what you are doing to move forward in life, such as finding a job and working with authorities to better your life. It is your opportunity to show the interviewer your personal growth and what you want your life to look like moving forward. However, be selective. Don't make everything about prison or your crime and keep it to the point.
  • Shield—holding your own: The last important piece of armor is your shield. Your shield guards you from things that may hurt your chance at getting the job you are interviewing for. Your shield is positive thinking, your personal strengths, and your goals. Sometimes, employers ask questions that can make us feel negative or put doubt in our minds, such as "Do you think you can perform the job duties given your criminal background?" These questions can surprise us if we are not ready for them. Luckily, you have your shield to help you deflect the negativity using positive thinking. If you used positive thinking, your response to that question could be "Yes, I do. In fact, I feel that my criminal background has helped prepare me to perform the job duties. I am a better person than I was before, I follow rules and respect authority. Plus, I have learned new skills like how to be a good leader and the importance of being a reliable employee." Answer these hard-hitting questions by not getting upset or criticizing the interviewer, not talking about other negative things, and telling the interviewer the things you do well.
pages.subheader: How to Use Your Interview Armor

pages.text: Let’s practice the skills that you just learned. Below are common interview questions that you will likely have to answer. Read the question, then write down what you think your response should be given your unique history. Look for the hintsto know which piece of armor to use for each question!

fields.text:
Interviewer: I see you answered 'yes' on your application to having a felony conviction. Can you tell me more about that? (Hint: use your sword and helmet!)
Your answer:

Interviewer: This job is pretty fast-paced and can get stressful. How do you think you would handle that? (Hint: use your shield!)
Your answer:

Interviewer: What would you say is your biggest weakness and why? (Hint: use your sword and shield!)
Your answer:

pages.text:
To better help you prepare, these are some other common interview questions. You should expect to get some version of at least a few of them.
  • Why should I hired you over other qualified candidates?
  • Give me an example of when you showed initiative and took the lead.
  • In what kind of work environment are you most comfortable?
  • How have your previous experiences prepared you for this job?
  • How would you describe yourself?
  • Where do you see yourself in 5-years from now? 10-years?
  • What interests you most about this job?
  • Why did you decide to seek a position with this company?
  • Tell me about a time you had to make a difficult decision.
  • How do you juggle all of your responsibilities to prioritize and stay organized?

The job hunt changes a lot when you go from submittingapplications to landing interviews. It is an exciting time, especially if this is your first job interview after being released from prison. Butour work isn’t over just yet. There are some tricky questions and situations that come upduring interviews orwhen talking with a potential boss. You may get asked about your convictions during an interview, or after you have already been offered a job and a criminal background check is completed. It can be aggravating to have to explain your criminal history allof the time. Between your community supervision officer and your job interviews, you can hardly catch a break! But there is a way to talk about your criminal history in job interviews and to your boss to protect your dignity and private information.
pages.subheader: Know Your Rights as a Job Candidate

pages.text: As you remember, the mystical being Oji went through a life-change too. Oji didn’t have to find a job like you do, but Oji certainly had to answer to other spiritual beings during his transformation. To turn his life around and get back his powers, Oji had to explain what he went through and what he learned from it. When Oji explained his story, he didn’t go into much detail –he quickly stated that he struggled with being arrogant and selfish,thenspent a lot of time explaining what he learned. He talked about the journey he took and how it changed his way of life. He finished by explaining to the spiritual leaders his new plan to create a wonderful place full of mountains and creatures who could live in peace. It was Oji’s focus on his growth and future plans that showed the spiritual leaders how much he had changed, and they were happy to grant him his powers and gifts back.

Employers have the right to know about some aspects of your criminal history, and it can have some impact on their hiring decisions, within limits. In some states, a person’s arrest record can change a hiring decision if the arrest is recent, if it is likely that you did it, and if the arrest is similar to what you would be doing in a job.So, if you were recently arrested for stealing your girlfriend’s car, and you are applying to work as a car valet driver, they may have some questions to ask and may hesitate to offer you the job. In most states, employers can ask about your arrest history during an interview.
Similarly, employers have the right to request a criminal background check and see if you have been convicted of any crimes before they employ you. This background check includes any offense that you have been convicted of, including traffic violations. If you were arrested for something but were never convicted of that offense, it will not show up on your criminal background check.
In some cases, your criminal background could prevent you from getting a certain type of job. For example, if you have a felony on your record, you are not allowed to have access to firearms. This would prevent you from working as a police officer or a security guard. It can also prevent you from working at banks or in positions where you have access to vulnerable people, such as children or the elderly.
This fact can be pretty disappointing. You and your supervising officer both know that you are trying to turn your life around and that you are a good person. You would not take advantage of your privileges in these position, but in the past people have. When people who have criminal records take advantage of their jobs and hurt people or steal, they spoil the opportunity for everyone else to find good jobs. Employers have to pay a lot of money and fix a lot of things when those kinds of things happen. It makes hiring people with criminal backgrounds in the future seem risky.

fields.text: What are some of your feelings after reading the ways an employer can use criminal records to make decisions? Are you disappointed, angry, scared? Write your thoughts below.

pages.text: Employers must follow laws and rules when asking and talking about your criminal history. An application can only ask if you have been convicted of any felonies, and it has to give you the opportunity to explain. They cannot ask you about arrests on the application. During an interview, they can ask about both conviction, and in some states, arrest history too. It’s really important that you are honest both on your application and during your interview on these questions. An employer can choose not to hire you if you lied about your criminal history, and can even fire you for it if they have already hired you and find out later! Make sure you know the difference between a conviction and an arrest so you can answer these questions honestly and accurately.
pages.subheader: What Rules Do Employers Have to Follow?

pages.text:
We already talked about some of the things that employers can’t do: ask you about arrest history on an application, choose not to hire you because you have been arrested in the past or because you have a criminal history. In some states, employers cannot ask about arrest history at all. A few states have passed laws making it illegal to ask about convictions on a job application, a social movement called “Ban the Box,” but this is still a new idea –so check your local laws before you accuse your potential employer of discriminating against offenders on their application!
We’ve also talked about some of the things that employers can do: ask questions about arrest history or convictions during an interview, choose not to hire you because you have been arrested 1) recently, 2) in connection to a crime you likely committed, or 3) in connection to a crime that is related to the job you are applying for; choose not to hire you because you have a conviction that directly prevents you from working in that job (can’t possess a firearm, work with children, etc.). Employers can also choose not to hire you, or to even fire you, if you are asked about your criminal history on an application or during an interview and lied in your answers.
If you finish an interview and realize your interviewer said or did something that goes against these rules, or they gave you a hiring decision and you feel like it was not within legal guidelines, there are a few things you need to do. The first thing to do is to pause. Think about what you are feeling and thinking. Are you angry that someone would discriminate against you? Are you sad that you didn’t get that job you were hoping for? Take note. Don’t react. It can be easy to call the employer an asshole for not hiring you, or even punching the window of the business as you walk out. These actions will make it even harder for you to get understanding and help in making a discrimination case, and it will just confirm the employer’s judgment: that people with convictions or arrests are dangerous and can’t be trusted.
Second, you want to ask someone you trust for their opinion on the situation. Talk to your community supervision officer, your counselor, and maybe an employee at the state department about what you experienced. Before you conclude that they discriminated against you, ask other people if they feel like you were discriminated against. Ask them to help you research your state’s hiring laws to confirm the rules in your area, as each state, and even city, is different.
If you and trusted others feel that you have been discriminated against, you can talk to your community supervising officer or counselor about obtaining legal resources to help you pursue the claim further.
pages.subheader: My Interviewer Discriminated Against Me –Now What?

pages.text: Read the following stories and decide whether it describes an arrest ora conviction. Then, write in the space provided the reasons for your answer.

fields.text: Rachel and her friends just left the bar after a night downtown. Rachel agreed to be the DD, so she drove her three friends in her friend’s car to the next bar. One of the girls sitting in the back decides to smoke some weed before they get to the next bar. Rachel, not thinking anything of it, continued to drive. Then – just her luck – she sees police car lights behind her. She quickly pulls over and gets her ID out. She wasn’t worried about the stop because she knew she hadn’t been drinking. It was probably just routine. During the routine stop, the police officer asked Rachel about the smell of weed in her car, then asked everyone to step out of the car so he could conduct a search. After finding the weed Rachel’s friend was smoking, the officer starts discussing the consequences. One of her friends, already drunk, began yelling at the officer and calling him a pig, and giving him the finger. The cop got tired of it and arrested them all. Rachel got out on bail luckily, but she has to appear in court next month to find out what will happen next.
Is this an arrest or conviction?
The reasons why:

After work one night, Ricky stopped by the liquor store to pick up some smokes and a 6-pack. It had been a long day and he needed to unwind. What better way than to watch the recording of the big game and have a few beers? While he was walking through the store, the clerk was watching him way to closely. He obviously had a problem. After a few minutes of the clerk staring him down, Ricky confronted him, asking him what the hell his problem was. The store clerk didn’t say much, but Ricky knew he had a problem and he was going to put a stop to it. Ricky egged on the store clerk some more, using racial slurs and pointing fingers at him. The clerk threatened to call the police if Ricky didn’t leave, which pissed him right off. He hadn’t even done anything yet? What would the police do? Finally, the clerk picked up the phone and dialed 911. Ricky smacked the phone out of his hand and punched the clerk in the jaw. The clerk hit the wall behind him and slowly crouched to the floor. Feeling satisfied, Ricky walked away from the clerk, grabbed his 6-pack of beer, and walked out of the store. The police pulled up as he was getting into his car, and he was arrested. A few weeks later, Ricky was charged with assault and theft. After spending 8 months in jail, Ricky was released on probation.
Is this an arrest or conviction?
The reasons why:

pages.text:
If you find yourself needing –or wanting –more resources related to finding a job, creating resumes, and landing job interviews, visit the websites below:
  • Find support networks in your area for families of previously incarcerated people: fcnetwork.org
  • Learn how to use online kiosks to apply for jobs: rileyguide.com/kiosk.html
  • Provide input on public policies and employment practices that affect previously incarcerated people’s ability to land a job: hirenetwork.org
  • Want to take the Holland code test again? https://openpsychometrics.org/tests/RIASEC/
  • Explore more jobs that, according to your Holland code type, would possibly be a good fit for you: https://www.career-lifeskills.com/pdf/jst-576530-occupations.pdf
  • Learn more about your rights as a person with a criminal history when looking for a job, and speak to someone when you feel you may have been discriminated against: eeoc.gov

In this Module you learned about:
  • Fears and unhelpful thoughts that may keep you from landing a job
  • How to talk about your job history with employers
  • Different types of jobs that align with your interests and skills
  • Good interviewing tips
  • Ways to make an impressive resume
  • Handling workplace discrimination

fields.text: Which of the goals that you learned about in this module are you going to focus on this week?
How will you accomplish your goal?
What might get in your way of accomplishing it?
What skills will you use to move past your road block?

pages.text: Now let's see what you learned! This quiz has 6 questions. Select the BEST possible answer to each question. Remember, you need to earn a score of 75% or above to move on to the next module!

questions.prompt: 1. What is the first thing you should do if you feel like your interviewer has discriminated against you?

answers.answer: a. Kick the trash can on your way out
d. Ask someone you trust for their opinion

questions.prompt: 2. What helps you make a good first impression during a job interview?

answers.answer: b. Have someone else make your resume for you
c. Only talk about the things you are good at
d. Ask the interviewer personal questions

questions.prompt: 3. How can positive thinking help you during an interview?

answers.answer: a. To help prevent you from getting discouraged by questions employers may ask about your history
b. So you don’t take lower end jobs
c. Allows you to make compromises, maintain self-confidence, and have control of your job choices

questions.prompt: 4. You should lie during a job interview if it makes you look better to the interviewer.
5. What things should you consider when looking for a job?

answers.answer: b. What job activities you can realistically complete
c. Only your most favorite interests

questions.correctAnswer: b. What job activities you can realistically complete

questions.prompt: 6. What should NOT be included in the employment history of your resume?

answers.answer: b. Jobs you did "under the table"

pages.text: Great work! You finished Module 7. Your supervision officer may need to review your work before you can move on to the next module and award your certificate.

Interviewer: I see you answered 'yes' on your application to having a felony conviction. Can you tell me more about that? (Hint: use your sword and helmet!)
Your answer:

Interviewer: This job is pretty fast-paced and can get stressful. How do you think you would handle that? (Hint: use your shield!)
Your answer:
New
